journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Additives for lubricants containing poly(tetrafluoroethylene). Part 1: Synthesis and rheological characterization

author-notes.corresp: T Hoffmann, Leibniz-Institut für Polymerforschung Dresden, Hohe Straße 6, 01069 Dresden, Germany. Email: hoffmann-thorsten@ipfdd.de

abstract.p: This article describes the synthesis of dispersions consisting of irradiated poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) micropowder in an ester oil (Synative ES TMP 05) and presents their results of the characterization in terms of stability and rheology.

The degree of PTFE micropowder in the dispersion was gradually increased from 10 wt% to 25 wt%. In addition, two additives based on phosphoric acid were used to study whether they are able to affect the properties of the dispersion with the lowest concentration of PTFE micropowder.

The amount of irradiated PTFE micropowder affects the stability against separation. The dispersion with the lowest concentration of PTFE micropowder (10 wt%) showed the highest stability due to the pronounced high fine fraction of PTFE particles (Ø: 0.2–0.5 µm). On the other hand, the PTFE/oil dispersions with higher concentrations own a distinctive amount of greater particles (Ø: 0.3–3.0 µm), suggesting a negative influence on the stability of the dispersions. Nevertheless, these dispersions can stabilize themselves by these structures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Irradiation of commercially poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) represents the usual way to obtain PTFE micropowder.1 Such an PTFE micropowder is commonly used as an additive in a wide variety of applications, for example, as an additive in lubricants.2,3 The preparation of PTFE micropowder by irradiation involves the generation of functional groups (carbonyl fluoride and carboxylic acid) and peroxy radicals.4–8 These radicals are statistically formed in the PTFE grain. However, only a small radical concentration was kept in the decomposed PTFE grain after the irradiation. These radicals are necessary for the coupling reactions between PTFE primary particle surfaces and oils having single or multiple olefinic non-saturated groups. Radical concentration of > 5 × 1017 spin/g of PTFE has proved as sufficient for coupling reactions.9 A new covalent bond arises, in which a permanent separation of charge between the non-polar PTFE particle surfaces and the olefinic non-saturated groups of the polar ester oil molecules exists and a fine dispersion of the PTFE articles in the oil is achieved.10 In this manner, stable dispersions originate, in which this chemical compatibilization reaction between ester oil and PTFE micropowder prevents the phase separation between both components.

We have studied the effect of the amount of PTFE micropowder as well as the influence of additives on the rheological properties (structural changes, dispersion stability) of the resulting PTFE/oil dispersions. Our investigations can contribute to an enhanced comprehension for the relationship between the amount of PTFE micropowder and the degree of coupling to the ester oil molecules as well as the extent of resulting structure in the oil dispersion on their rheological behaviour.

sec.title: Trimethylolpropane trioleate (polyol complex ester)
sec.p:
The ester oil trimethylolpropane trioleate (Synative ES TMP 05) was used as received from ILCO-Chemikalien GmbH, Germany. The chemical structure is shown in Scheme 1 and some properties are summarized in Table 1.11 Scheme 1.
Chemical structure of trimethylolpropane trioleate (TMP 05). Table 1.
Properties of the ester oil used for coupling reactions with PTFE micropowder.10
Oil ANa (mg KOH/g) HNb INc (g/100 g) SNd (mg KOH/g) ρe (g/cm3) VIf
TMP 05 1.385 Maximum 20 83–90 178–187 0.917 180
a
Acid number, determined by potentiometric titration (Metrohm, Germany) according to DIN 53402. b
Hydroxyl number, determined according to DIN 53240. c
Iodine number, determined according to DGF C-V 11 b. d
Saponification number, determined according to DIN 53401. e
Density, at 20 °C (DIN 51757V4). f
Viscosity index, determined according to DIN ISO 2909.

sec.title: Poly(tetrafluoroethylene)
sec.p: The PTFE was irradiated (500 kGy) by DuPont AG and used as received by C.H. Erbslöh KG, Germany. The PTFE micropowder was obtained as Zonyl® MP 1100. Zonyl® MP 1100, irradiated with 500 kGy, possesses an average radical concentration of 1018 spin/g of PTFE and an average particle size of 4 µm.

sec.title: Additives
sec.p:
Two additives on the basis of phosphoric acid (Crafol AP-24, Crafol AP-63) were used as received from Cognis Iberia S.A., Spain and their chemical structures and properties are shown in Scheme 2 and Table 2.12 Scheme 2.
Chemical structures of the Crafol additives: (a) phosphoric acid isotrideceyl ester and (b) phosphoric acid dodecyl/tetradecyl ethoxy alcohol monoester. Table 2.
Properties of the Crafol additives.11
Additive ANa (mg KOH/g) pHb ρc (g/cm3) Application
Crafol AP-24 156/258 2.98 0.990 Anti-static agent
Crafol AP-63 110/185 1.66 1.014 Lubricating additive, surfactant
a
Acid number, determined by potentiometric titration (Metrohm, Germany) according to DIN 53402. b
pH-Value, 20 °C, 10% in H2O, according to EN 1262 (96). c
Density, at 20 °C, according to ASTM D 1298-99.

sec.title: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy
sec.p: The IR spectra were recorded using the Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer Vertex 80v (Bruker, Germany) in transmission mode (32 scans, 2 cm−1 resolution, 4000–400 cm−1). Powders were pressed into films at room temperature (thickness ∼ 150 µm). For calibration of the spectra, the band at 2365 cm−1 ((−CF2−)n backbone) was used as an internal standard for the scaling of the same film thickness.

sec.title: Electron spin resonance spectroscopy
sec.p: The electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra were recorded with an ESR spectrometer MiniScope, MS 200 (MagnetTech GmbH, Germany) at room temperature. The modulation amplitude was 0.1 mT and the microwave power 1.0 mW.

sec.title: Analysis of the separation stability
sec.p: This analysis allows the direct and faster stability analysis as well as the comprehensive characterization of particle properties and interactions by the use of the Dispersion Analyser LUMiSizer® 611 (LUM GmbH, Germany).

The course of the transmission was recorded in preselected intervals over the entire length of the sample. The modification of the local concentration of the dispersed particles was quantified by the weakening of the emitted light. The properties of the separation processes can be determined from the shape and the course of the measured transmission profiles. The principle is shown in Sobisch and Lerche.13 The separation of the PTFE particles in the dispersions was followed at ϑ = 20 °C by a strongly raised centrifugal acceleration at 2300 × g for 2 h. To study the shear-dependent separation, the measurements were repeated at lower centrifugal acceleration at 328 × g for 15 h.

sec.title: Rheological characterization
sec.p: The rheological characterization was performed by a rotational rheometer MCR 301 (Anton Paar, Germany) at ϑ = 20 °C to conduct stress and strain experiments in oscillation mode to prove the structures formed within the PTFE-containing dispersions as the function of the amount of PTFE micropowder.

All measurements were conducted using the direct strain oscillation (DSO) option at a constant angular frequency ω = 1 rad/s. The shear deformation was raised from γ = 0.05% to 100% in the amplitude-sweeps. The frequency-sweeps were carried out at a constant shear deformation γ = 0.05%.

sec.title: Characterization of Zonyl® MP 1100
sec.p: The used PTFE micropowder Zonyl® MP 1100 was characterized by FTIR and ESR spectroscopic methods in order to analyse the initial concentration of functional groups and radicals.

The overall concentration of functional groups of Zonyl® MP 1100 was analytically determined by FTIR spectroscopy according to Buckmaster et al.14 The bands in the IR absorbance spectrum of PTFE could be assigned to carbonyl fluoride and free and associated carboxylic acid groups as the functional groups of MP 1100 (Table 3). Table 3.
Investigations of Zonyl® MP 1100: evidence of functional groups (from FTIR analysis).
[−COF]a /106 CF2 νC = O at 1884a cm−1 [−COOHfree]a /106 CF2 νC = O at 1810 cm−1 [−COOH assoc.]a /106 CF2 νC = O at 1777 cm−1 [Total]a/106 CF2
603 177 498 1278
a
Determined by FTIR investigation, related on the FTIR band at 2365 cm−1, which refers to the (−CF2−)n backbone of MP 1100.

In addition, by means of differential scanning calorimetric measurements of MP 1100, the molecular weight of 250,000 g/mol was determined from the re-crystallization enthalpy. The morphology of MP 1100 was investigated by scanning electron microscopy and is characterized by clusters of primary particles (0.2–0.5 µm). These clusters are common for an emulsion polymer and characterized by dimensions from more than 5 µm (Figure 1). Figure 1.
SEM micrograph of MP1100 in 10,000-fold enlargement shows a cluster of primary particles of the PTFE micropowder.
By means of the ESR spectroscopy, the relative signal intensity per milligram of sample was identified and amounts for Zonyl® MP 1100 a radical concentration of 746 mg/spin.

sec.title: Preparation of PTFE/oil dispersions
sec.p:
These coupling reactions are dependent on what extent the used dispersion technique favors the reaction between the radicals of the PTFE primary particles with the double bonds of the oil molecules. The accessibility of the radicals is the important pre-condition for such radical-induced coupling reactions. Satisfying results are obtained using temperatures higher than 100 °C, namely an appropriate shear strain using an Ultra-Turrax disperser (IKA, Germany) in the dispersion, and an adequate long dispersion period according to the literature.10 The reaction pathway is schematically illustrated in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Scheme of the reaction between PTFE micropowder and olefinic non-saturated groups of the oil (e.g. Synative ES TMP 05).

Synative ES TMP 05 was used as ester oil in all dispersion experiments. The content of PTFE micropowder differs from 10 wt% to 25 wt% in these oil dispersions and the results of individual dispersion experiments are summarized in Table 4. The dispersions No. 2 and No. 3 differ from dispersion No. 1 only by the additional application of the additives Crafol AP-24 and Crafol AP-63 to each 1 wt%. Table 4.
Preparation of PTFE/oil dispersions.
Number Ester oil Additive PTFE micropowder
Type wt% Type wt%
1 Synative ES TMP 05 – – MP 1100 10
2 Synative ES TMP 05 AP-24 10 MP 1100 10
3 Synative ES TMP 05 AP-63 10 MP 1100 10
4 Synative ES TMP 05 – – MP 1100 17.5
5 Synative ES TMP 05 – – MP 1100 20
6 Synative ES TMP 05 – – MP 1100 25
PTFE: poly(tetrafluoroethylene).

All PTFE/oil dispersions were purified after the coupling reactions by repeated washing in petroleum benzine in order to remove non-reacted ester oil. A white powder (referred to as ‘extract’) was obtained after this treatment and used for the characterization of the growth of the intensity of the ester oil band (FTIR spectroscopy).

sec.title: FTIR spectroscopy
sec.p: The evidence of the chemical coupling between the PTFE micropowder and the oil was indirectly proved by FTIR spectroscopy by tracing the growing oil ester band (1744–1747 cm−1) in the extracts of the purified PTFE/oil dispersions.

The spectrum of the extract of the 1st PTFE/oil dispersion (No. 1) (10 wt% PTFE) acts as the substitution for the other PTFE/oil dispersions presented here and is shown in Figure 3, together with the spectra of the starting materials (MP 1100, ester oil). The FTIR bands at 3557 cm−1 (−COOHfree) and 3105 cm−1 (−COOHassoc.) could be assigned to the νOH from free and associated (H-bonded) carboxylic acid groups. The FTIR bands at 1884, 1810, and 1777 cm−1 are caused by the νC = O of both carbonyl fluoride and of free and associated carboxylic acid groups from MP 1100, which are formed during the irradiation procedure. The FTIR band at 2365 cm−1 corresponds to (−CF2−)n backbone of MP 1100 and was used for calibration. Figure 3.
FTIR spectra of PTFE (MP 1100), TMP 05, and the PTFE/oil dispersion (No. 1) in the spectral region 1600–3700 cm−1.
The new FTIR band at 1744 cm−1 originates the νC = O of the oil ester groups and indicates the presence of ester oil molecules that are linked with the PTFE grains.

The presence of this ester band in the FTIR spectra of the extracts, prepared by purification of the PTFE/oil dispersions, is valid as an indirect proof of the chemical coupling between the PTFE radicals and the olefinic non-saturated groups of the ester oil.

The rise of the intensity of the ester band corresponds with the duration of the dispersion period that could be proven by the investigation of intermediate samples, which were taken during the preparation procedure of the dispersions. The intensity of the ester oil band, which was determined after ending of the reaction in the respective extracts, is given in Table 5 for all dispersions. Table 5.
FTIR analysis of the extracts, monitoring the intensity of the ester oil band (νC = O) in the range 1744–1747 cm−1.
Number PTFE micropowder Additive Ester oil band into the extracts
Type wt% Type wt% cm−1 Intensity of νC = O band
1 MP 1100 10 – – 1744 0.727
2 MP 1100 10 AP-24 1 1747 0.369
3 MP 1100 10 AP-63 1 1747 0.454
4 MP 1100 17.5 – – 1745 0.655
5 MP 1100 20 – – 1745 0.586
6 MP 1100 25 – – 1745 0.628

An evaluation of the degree of coupling is possible if the intensities of the ester bands in the FTIR spectrum of all extracts (Nos 1–6) were determined and compared with each other. As expected, the differences are low between the dispersions, because the coupling degree primarily depends on the duration of preparation and the temperature that were kept constant in all cases. However, the additives in the dispersions No. 2 and No. 3 can influence this result disadvantageously and disturb the reaction between the radicals and the olefinic non-saturated groups of the oil, in which the hydrophobic chains of the additives insulated the PTFE grain. Both these dispersions show the lowest intensity of the absorption band at 1747 cm−1.

By the use of the relative signal intensity per milligram sample of the dispersions, tracing of the radical concentration was possible by means of ESR spectroscopy before and after these coupling reactions. In the initial state, MP 1100 possesses a radical concentration of (746 mg/spin). After the coupling reaction, e.g. with 25 wt% MP 1100 in TMP 05, a strong drop of the radical concentration was observed (4 mg/spin).
The characterization of the separation stability as well as the rheological and tribological properties was directly performed in the PTFE/oil dispersions.

sec.title: Separation stability tests
sec.p: The PTFE-containing dispersions were characterized in terms of stability, the effect of the PTFE concentration, and the structure of PTFE which has formed in the oil dispersions. The influence of the additives on the dispersion stability was studied as well.

The investigation was started at 2300 × g for 2 h. The separation behaviour of the dispersion No. 1 points out that the PTFE particle separates roughly at the same velocity. This dispersion has the lowest separation velocity as the result of the large amount of fine and well-distributed PTFE particles. Both dispersions, which contain additional additives, show the quickest separation. Their separation behaviour is typical for flocculated particle networks, i.e., the resistance against further compression increases with the degree of the separation. Although the differences are relatively low between the additives, the dispersion with Crafol AP-24 separates faster. This is caused by the forced separation of the fine fraction, which is not firmly bound on the particle network. This fine fraction is stronger in the dispersion containing the additive Crafol AP-63. The other dispersions, which have higher PTFE concentrations, are polydisperse and show a similar separation behaviour. According to their PTFE concentrations, the height of the sediment varies.

For conducting the investigation of the shear-dependent separation, the measurements were repeated at lower centrifugal acceleration and longer measuring time (at 328 × g, for 15 h). Only the dispersion No. 1 possesses a steady separation behaviour independent of the acceleration. The other dispersions show shear thinning behaviour, because the degree of separation decreases. At the dispersions with high PTFE concentrations, the separation of the fine fraction becomes higher with partly distinctive polydisperse separation character. The large fine fraction (0.2–0.5 µm) of 70% in the dispersion No. 1 might be responsible for the higher stability against separation in comparison to the other dispersions, in which particle dimensions in the range 0.3–3 µm were detected and roughly the same distribution was found. Only the dispersion No. 6 (25 wt% PTFE) owns higher coarse fraction. In both dispersions containing additives, particle distributions in the range 0.25–2.5 µm were proved. The dispersion with the additive Crafol AP-63 is shifted to smaller particle dimensions (Figure 4). Figure 4.
Study of the influence of the phosphoric acid-derived additives on the particle size distribution of PTFE/oil dispersions No. 1 (unmodified), No. 2 (modified with Crafol AP-24), and No. 3 (modified with Crafol AP-63).

Both additives increase the separation velocity clearly and change the separation behaviour of the PTFE/oil dispersion (No. 1) from a steady separation behaviour to flocculated particle networks. That means that a change of the kinetic of the sedimentation process occurred by a modification of the particle interactions.13 The kinetic of the separation shows a ranking order of the separation stability that is independent from the centrifugal acceleration.

sec.title: Rheological characterization
sec.p: These PTFE-containing oil dispersions were followed by the DSO option in oscillating mode both as amplitude-sweep and as frequency-sweep at ϑ = 20 °C. In the DSO mode, a stress τ(t) is applied at the time (t) and the resulting strain γ(t) is measured. The structural properties of the dispersion were characterized into the dependence of the deformation (γ) (by means of amplitude-sweeps) and into the dependence of the angular frequency (ω) (using frequency-sweeps), as well. Detailed information is given in the following literature.15

In particular, an influence on the long time stability of the dispersions is expected by the temperature gradient and the concentration of the micropowder. In addition, the effect of two of phosphoric acid-containing additives (Crafol AP-24, Crafol AP-63) on the rheological behaviour (elastic behaviour) of the dispersion, which characterizes the lowest PTFE amount, was additionally examined.

In Figure 5, the storage modulus (G′) and the loss modulus (G″) are plotted versus the deformation. The storage modulus represents the elastic properties and the loss modulus the viscous. In the linear-viscous elastic (LVE) deformation area, we observe the liquid character of the ester oil and the dispersions No. 1, No. 2, and No. 4 (G″ > G′). In contrast, the dispersions No. 3, No. 5, and No. 6 exhibit gel character (G′ > G″). The evaluation of the yield point, the cross-over point (G′ = G″), as well as the flow point of the PTFE/oil dispersions was performed for all dispersions and summarized in Table 6. For the evaluation of the structural strength, the values of the storage modulus (G′) were taken, which are specified in Table 6, as well. Figure 5.
Amplitude-sweep in controlled shear stress of PTFE/oil dispersions consisting of varying amounts of PTFE in comparison with the neat ester oil (Synative ES TMP 05). Table 6.
PTFE/oil dispersions: evaluation of the results obtained from amplitude-sweep.
Number PTFE (wt%) Additive Cross-over point G′ (Pa) τ (Pa)
Type (wt%) G′ = G″ (Pa) γ (%)
0 – – – – – 0.03 –
1 10 – – – – 0.05 –
2 10 AP-63 1 – – 1 0.59
3 10 AP-24 1 5 0.80 8 0.39
4 17.5 – – – – 0.1 –
5 20 – – 85 4.37 238 4.07
6 25 – – 358 0.53 905 1.80

An increased amount of deformation energy was consumed to achieve the yield point during the shear process. This behaviour is typical of many dispersions and it is shown by the rise of the loss modulus (G″) near the cross-over points of the dispersions No. 5 and No. 6. However, the course of the loss modulus of such dispersions is different and does not directly depend on the PTFE amount applied, as shown by the dispersion No. 6, which was characterized by the longest LVE area. Thus, no direct influence of the amount of PTFE micropowder on the structural strength is visible since counter-moving processes superimpose this influence.

The curves of the PTFE/oil dispersions shown in Figure 5 can be divided based on their curve course into three groups. The dispersions of the first group do not differ from the rheological behaviour of the ester oil. This group has a completely viscous behaviour and shows no yield point. The second group reflects the influence of the additives on rheological properties of dispersion No. 1, which undergoes a considerable increase in structural strength and exhibits a yield point. In the third group, the increasing influence of the PTFE concentration becomes clear in the dispersions, in which viscoelastic fractions was induced by the increased PTFE concentration in the dispersion. In addition, the 25-wt% dispersion (No. 6) showed a cross-over point at the lowest deformation and the highest amount for the deformation work that possibly represents the effect of the varying PTFE particle sizes, which had been identified in the separation tests.

The effect of Crafol AP-24 as an additive in the dispersion No. 1 clearly appears by the shift of the curve to higher shear strain values and a yield point is additionally visible. Although both additives possess a similar chemical structure, the extent of the impact on the rheological properties, e.g. the yield point, of the dispersion No. 1 is different, as shown in Figure 5.

Another way to represent the properties of the PTFE/oil dispersions in the amplitude-sweep is by drawing the plot of the loss factor (tan δ) versus the deformation, as shown in Figure 6. The loss factor is calculated as the quotient of the loss and the stored deformation energy and indicates the relationship between the viscous and the elastic parts of the viscoelastic deformation behaviour. The viscous part of the viscoelastic deformation predominates in the PTFE/oil dispersions No. 1, No. 3, and No. 4. Particularly, the PTFE/oil dispersions (No. 5 and No. 6) exhibit a pronounced elastic part at tan δ ∼ 0.1 that is independent from the deformation up to 0.06%. Figure 6.
Amplitude-sweep of PTFE/oil dispersions containing varying amounts of PTFE in comparison with the neat ester oil (Synative ES TMP 05).

As already described, the influence of the additives on the viscoelastic behaviour of the PTFE/oil dispersion No. 1 is clearly observable in Figure 6. The effect of the additive Crafol AP-24 is strong enough to induce an elastic part in the PTFE/oil dispersion No. 1.

The viscoelastic behaviour of No. 1 is characterized only by the viscous part, in contrast to the PTFE/oil dispersions No. 5 and No. 6, which displayed the highest concentration of PTFE micropowder. Here, the elastic part is more pronounced. This conclusion could be confirmed by frequency-sweeps, as shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Frequency-sweep (γ: 0.05% deformation) of PTFE/oil dispersions containing varying amounts of PTFE (No. 1, No. 4, No. 5, and No. 6).

The deformation value of γ = 0.05 was chosen from the evaluation of the amplitude-sweep. At this deformation, no irreversible deformation behaviour was observed. For the PTFE/oil dispersions No. 5 and No. 6, the absolute values of complex viscosity |η*| showed a linear slope as expected for systems with an elastic part. The high level of G′ at ω = 0.04 rad/s of these dispersions indicates the strength of the structure in rest (No. 5: G′ = 238 Pa and No. 6: G′ = 905 Pa). This means that both dispersions are stabilized by the formation of physical network structures. This behaviour is typical for stable dispersions, because a three-dimensional network was established by the effect of the intermolecular interaction.16 On the other hand, the viscoelastic behaviour of the PTFE/oil dispersion No. 1 was similar to that of the neat ester oil and characterized only by the viscous part.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article describes the preparation of PTFE/oil dispersions, which consists of an polar ester oil and PTFE micropowder (Zonyl® MP 1100) in varying amounts from 10 wt% to 25 wt%. Dispersions were prepared by the reaction between radicals of PTFE micropowder and the olefinic non-saturated groups of the ester oil to use them as additives in lubricants to enhance their lubricating properties, e.g. extreme pressure behaviour and wear resistance. The obtained PTFE/oil dispersions were investigated by rheological characterization and by the study of the stability against separation under enhanced centrifugal acceleration.

It was found that the quantity of PTFE micropowder affects the separation stability. The dispersion with the lowest concentration of PTFE micropowder (10 wt%) showed the highest stability against separation due to the pronounced high fine fraction of PTFE particles (0.2–0.5 µm) in this dispersion. However, this property causes no formation of any structures in the dispersion. Therefore, two additives on the base of phosphoric acid were used to study whether they are able to affect the properties of the PTFE/oil dispersion with only 10 wt% of PTFE micropowder (No. 1). Both additives increase the separation velocity clearly and change the separation behaviour of the PTFE/oil dispersion (No. 1) from a steady separation behaviour to flocculated particle networks. It means that a change of the kinetic of the sedimentation process occurred by a modification of the particle interactions. In addition, study of the influence of these additives on the viscoelastic behaviour of the PTFE/oil dispersion (No. 1) was followed by rheological investigations. The effect of the additive Crafol AP-24 is strong enough to induce an elastic part in the PTFE/oil dispersion No. 1.
In another article, the question shall be answered whether these structures are able to change the tribological properties of the PTFE/oil dispersions.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the BMBF Innovationsinitiative Neue Länder [grant no. 03FO2172].

ack.p: The authors thank Mrs C. Kutschera for the preparation and purification of PTFE/oil dispersions, Mrs G. Adam for FTIR measurements, and Mrs K. Szabang for the determination of acid numbers by potentiometric titration (all from Leibniz-Institut für Polymerforschung Dresden, Germany), and Dr T. Sobisch for the stabilization tests of the PTFE/oil dispersions (LUM GmbH, Berlin, Germany), and for the kind delivery of the additives (Cognis Iberia S.A., Spain) and the ester oil (ILCO Chemikalien GmbH, Germany).
